incidents.name: Some postgres databases are experiencing downtime

incident_updates.body:
# RCA

# Summary

On Thursday November 9th, multiple databases were restarted across all regions due to unexpected restarts triggered by a code change. This code change caused databases to be unavailable for up to 8 minutes. A concurrent but unrelated bug caused some affected databases in the Ohio region to be down for up to 37 minutes.

## Incident Timeline

# Impact

This incident affected a subset of Point-In-Time Recovery-enabled Postgres instances which experienced an unexpected restart during this time. The event resolved itself between 3 and 8 minutes in each cluster, except for the Ohio region.

In the Ohio region, we were unable to scale up to handle the movement of databases. This extended downtime. We rolled back a separate change to resolve the issues with scale up. All affected databases became available again within 37 minutes. 2 Postgres instances in the Ohio region remained unavailable and had to be manually returned to service by an engineer.

# Root Cause

This downtime was triggered by a code deploy of our database management system. The code change created an errant configuration change to specific database configurations which caused them to unexpectedly restart to pick up the new configuration.

# Mitigations

* We will improve monitoring and alerting to decrease our time to detection.
* We will add additional guard rails to our database management system to prevent unintentional restarts, including those due to configuration changes. We have already developed the feature and are planning its roll out.
* We will improve our database management system to prevent the configuration change of this incident from triggering a restart.
* We will add additional testing to detect restart-triggering changes before we deploy them.
incident_updates.custom_tweet: We published a postmortem on our November 9th incident: https://stspg.io/cx6gz8wqkxpf

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
All affected Postgres databases have recovered
We're seeing recovery for Postgres databases across all regions. We're continuing to investigate
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are currently investigating this issue.

incidents.name: Issues with new services, custom domains, and certificates

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
We are continuing to monitor the upstream provider. After the issue is resolved upstream, we will examine and reconcile any affected services on our platform.

We continue to monitor an outage with an upstream provider that is impacting new services, certificates and domains on our platform.

New services can be created, but new custom domains will remain in a 'pending' state. This also affects:
- Delays issuing custom domain certificates
- Traffic to new services will be slower until they can be routed directly to their region

We're tracking an incident with Cloudflare (https://www.cloudflarestatus.com/) that is impacting the ability to issue certificates for custom domains. Newly added custom domains will be showing as 'pending'.

At the moment, we don't believe there is any further impact to our service.

incidents.name: Past deployments being made live

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.

The fix was fully deployed as of 4:50pm Pacific. Engineering is re-deploying all affected services in order to ensure that they are running the latest successful deployment as expected. Affected services will see a "Triggered by Render" note for a deployment invoked between 5:00pm and 5:30pm Pacific.

Services that use a Pre-Deploy Command may experience an issue where a previous deploy is made live approximately 2 hours later. This is problematic when multiple deploys take place over a 2 hour period, and suddenly code from multiple deployments back is seen executing again.

For example; if a service was deployed at 11:00am, 11:30am, and 12:15am, then around 1:00pm the 11:00am deployment may be seen again unexpectedly.

This issue would only occur on services that use a Pre-Deploy command after one is configured, and only when multiple deploys within 2 hours take place.

A fix for the past deployment being made live is already complete, and is being deployed.

incidents.name: Large WebSocket messages reported to be failing

incident_updates.body:
# Summary

Render uses Cloudflare Workers as an HTTP proxy layer, for managing caching and cached requests, for all customers. A deploy to our Cloudflare Workers introduced new behavior around WebSocket compression, that mixed compressed and uncompressed messages and caused WebSocket client errors. The regression in behavior was manually reported and then disabled.

# Impact

The regression was active for 17 hours, enabled around 2023-10-04 18:46Z \(11:46a PT\) and disabled at 2023-10-05 12:06Z \(05:06a PT\). Several customers using large messages depended on this behavior and helped report and identify the issue.

# Root Cause

During a deploy to enable additional logging in the Cloudflare Workers, a new Cloudflare feature around WebSocket Compression was enabled and included in that deploy. Cloudflare Workers do offer flags to prevent new features from being enabled, but Render did not specifically block this feature from being enabled.

With the WebSocket Compression feature enabled, new WebSocket connections would attempt to use compression and mix compressed and uncompressed data. Messages over 1MB of data then resulted in WebSocket 1002 or 1009 errors on the client or server.

Once the Render support and engineering was aware of the regression, several production changes were reverted until the Cloudflare Workers deployment was identified as the cause. The previous Cloudflare Workers deployment was then rolled back.

# Mitigations

* Render has disabled the Cloudflare Workers feature around WebSocket Compression for the near-term
* Render has added end to end regression testing around this WebSocket behavior with large messages
* Render is creating an automated test suite, actively testing live WebSocket behavior

Customers making large websocket requests (>1Mib) may have received errors about the message being too large. The cause has been identified and reverted.

Customer impact was between 2023-10-04 1846UTC and 2023-10-05 1206UTC

incidents.name: Services hosted in Frankfurt are unreachable

incident_updates.body:
# Summary

Render uses AWS Elastic Block Store \(EBS\) as a storage provider in several of our clusters, and we were affected by an issue with the service:

> Between 5:10 AM and 8:40 AM PDT, we experienced a performance degradation for a small number of EBS volumes in a single Availability Zone \(euc1-az3\) in the EU-CENTRAL-1 Region.

The issue resulted in downtime for some Postgres & Redis services, and degradation in some behaviors like autoscaling, builds, deploys, and metrics.

# Impact

An estimated 3,000 managed Postgres and Redis instances experienced downtime, and even more will have experienced degraded performance.

Additionally, the Render platform in Frankfurt experienced general degradation in, but not limited to, autoscaling, builds, deploys, and metrics.

# Root Cause

Render's automated alerting detected ongoing issues in one of our Frankfurt clusters at 12:40 UTC. We responded by opening a public incident. As part of the response, we identified that some of our hosts were experiencing severely degraded EBS performance.

Render uses AWS EBS to power storage volumes for all managed Postgres services in the Frankfurt region. Due to the outage, EBS volumes became detached from hosts. Our system automatically attempted to recover by attaching the volume to a new host, but failed to do so because of degradation in the attach/detach API. Eventually these attach operations succeeded; by 13:51 UTC, service was restored to all managed Postgres instances.

EBS also provides the storage for our etcd cluster, which runs as part of the Kubernetes cluster. Because etcd's consensus algorithm requires every member to write to disk on every proposal, high disk latency for just one member can slow down the entire etcd cluster. Our Kubernetes API server, which regularly transacts with etcd, became sluggish and slow to process requests that support behaviors like autoscaling, builds, deploys, and metrics. After identifying the failure mode, at 13:25 UTC we removed the unhealthy etcd member from the cluster. This allowed most of the degraded behaviors to recover.

# Mitigations

* We have been in contact with the AWS team to discuss near- and long-term mitigations.
* We have added alerting on Render's end that is targeted at identifying when etcd is experience poor disk performance. It will help us to more quickly identify and remove the slow member in the cluster.
incident_updates.custom_tweet: We published a postmortem on our September 7th incident: https://stspg.io/5f9q88bzhdjt

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
We've implemented the necessary changes and are seeing progressive recovery for services and databases. We're monitoring.
We have identified the degraded component and are working to restore service.
We're seeing that services in the Frankfurt region are un-reachable, we're investigating

incidents.name: Websites and APIs on Render are unavailable due to Cloudflare network errors

incident_updates.body:
# Summary

Render uses Cloudflare to offer DDoS protection to all web services and as a CDN provider for static sites. A configuration change made by Cloudflare triggered a bug in Cloudflare systems, causing all Render web services and static sites to respond with a `500` HTTP error between 2023-08-11 4:00 UTC and 2023-08-11 5:26 UTC. Service was restored after Cloudflare reverted the change.

# Impact

Between 4:00 UTC and 5:26 UTC, all HTTP traffic to web services and static sites hosted on Render received a Cloudflare Internal Server Error \(HTTP error code `500`\). Traffic to [render.com](http://render.com) and [dashboard.render.com](http://dashboard.render.com) was also impacted.

# Root Cause

Render uses Cloudflare for DDoS protection for all HTTP services, and as a CDN for static sites. All requests to Render are therefore proxied through the closest Cloudflare data center. At 2023-08-11 4:00 UTC, Cloudflare added a rule to place an interstitial page in front of a specific Render-hosted website in response to a verified report of phishing. The application of this rule triggered a bug in the Cloudflare request processing engine, which resulted in all Render services, our dashboard, and [render.com](http://render.com) returning HTTP `500` errors.

Render's automated alerting brought the issue to our attention at 2023-08-11 4:01 UTC, and we responded by escalating the issue to Cloudflare and opening a public incident at 4:05. Given the severe and extensive impact of the outage, we coordinated with several members of the Cloudflare team while also investigating several options to restore services as quickly as possible. One of these investigations explored ways to temporarily circumvent Cloudflare's network to serve requests directly from Render's origin servers. We were able to deploy a working solution for [dashboard.render.com](http://dashboard.render.com) at 5:03 UTC; this solution was manual and specific to the [dashboard.render.com](http://dashboard.render.com) subdomain. We also began investigating ways to roll this solution out more broadly with customer assistance that would have involved updating their DNS records. Cloudflare identified the issue and rolled back the triggering rule at 5:26 UTC.

# Mitigations

## Completed

* Over the last week, Render's engineering team worked closely with Cloudflare support and engineering teams to discuss near-term mitigations and longer-term solutions.
* Cloudflare rolled back the original change and added validation to prevent this bug in the future.

## Planned

* Render will automate and test mechanisms to temporarily route HTTP requests directly to Render in similarly extreme cases.
* Render will investigate provider redundancy options to enable faster failure recovery.
* In their RCA, Cloudflare shared additional recommended mitigations for their systems. We will continue to work together to put these in place.
Service has been fully restored.
Cloudflare has implemented a fix and we're monitoring.
We are working with the Cloudflare team to determine a fix. We're separately also looking into ways you can bypass Cloudflare for your Render services.
We're working with the Cloudflare team to restore access. You can also follow https://www.cloudflarestatus.com for updates.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are in touch with the Cloudflare team and investigating.

incidents.name: Static Site deployments failing with error "poetry: command not found"

incident_updates.body:
Static Sites began failing to deploy at approximately 12:30 PM Pacific. Deploy logs contained a line of output stating: "/home/render/python-env.sh: line 114: poetry: command not found"

We found that a recent deployment introduced a bug and began rolling it back. The rollback across all regions was completed just before 3 PM Pacific. Static Site deployments that started after this rollback completed no longer encountered the error.

incidents.name: Request failures for static sites

incident_updates.body: Static sites experienced intermittent request failures between 07:28 AM PT and 07:34 AM PT. The root cause was a sophisticated DDoS attack that evaded our existing DDoS protection settings. We have enabled additional DDoS protection rules to prevent similar attacks in the future.

incidents.name: Intermittently missing metrics for some users in oregon

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
The metrics graphs for services have gaps for some users in Oregon. We have identified the issue and are working on a fix.

incidents.name: Degraded deployments and dashboard experience

incident_updates.body: We have identified the problem and pushed out a fix.
We're seeing degraded experience with our internal api. This impact is a degraded experience of deployments and any operations on the dashboard.

incidents.name: Investigating issue with builds, deploys, and free tier issues in Oregon

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
All affected builds, deploys, and free tier services have recovered.
We are continuing to work on a fix for this issue.

The origin of the build, deploy, and free tier service issues has been identified & fixed, with initial impact from 15:45 - 16:00 PDT. Engineers are working to identify whether any services remain in an erroneous state.
We are investigating and working to resolve an issue in Oregon affecting builds, deploys, and free tier services.

incidents.name: Network Issues in Oregon Region

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.

We are monitoring networking issues for a subset of services in the Oregon region. Service timeouts and HTTP 502s would have been recevied for 2 minutes from 2023-05-16 19:10:00 UTC to 2023-05-16 19:12:00.
